Award.AwardTitle: Time Effects in Sand: Delayed Micro-Cracking, Contact Fatigue, and Aging

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The strength of soils can change over time, and therefore affect the performance of structures resting on them. Silica sand, after a disturbance caused by natural events such as earthquakes, or after compaction by vibratory means, can exhibit a weakening-like behavior. However, a gradual improvement of strength is observed in time following the disturbance. There is no consensus among researchers as to what the key causes of such behavior are, and this research addresses some of the fundamental questions regarding time effects. The immediate impact of this research will be on the broad area of physical infrastructure; it will allow for better planning of construction processes and more educated predictions of civil infrastructure behavior, and thus will benefit society at large. This research will also have a broader impact, for instance in chemical and pharmaceutical industries,where operations involve powders and granular materials. Finally, material aging is an important process in extraterrestrial environments. Aging and contact fatigue caused by thermal cycling is believed to be responsible for the elevated density of the near-surface layer of lunar soil (regolith). The knowledge of this phenomenon will be important in planning for exploration of the Moon and Mars environments.

This research is to address the fundamental issue: what causes time-dependent behavior in silica sand? A hypothesis is explored that identifies fracturing of microscopic textural features on grain surfaces at inter-granular contacts as the key cause of this behavior. This fracturing does not stop at the end of the loading process, but continues at constant load, with a decaying rate. Experimental evidence will be gathered from tests on individual contacts. Custom-designed testing equipment will be constructed. Sand grain surfaces will be characterized using atomic force microscopy and scanning electron microscopy. The process of delayed fracturing finds its justification in the rate process concept, and it is expected to answer some of the fundamental questions regarding factors affecting crack propagation and healing. Mathematical description of the contact fatigue process will be sought through constructing a model with individual grains comprised of sub-particles fused together with bonds capable of carrying both forces and moments. Cracking in the model will be simulated by the stress corrosion process causing debonding of sub-particles within the contact regions between grains. The model will mimic the physical behavior of contacts in silica sand.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soils and rocks provide support for civil engineering infrastructure, be it high-rise office buildings, bridges, or airfields. Time effects in soils and rocks can affect the performance of the infrastructure during its service. This research focused on the mechanisms that cause the time-dependent response of soils to applied loads, and the research was concentrated on the micromechanics of interactions between sand grains. A custom-designed testing apparatus was constructed to assess the time dependency of microscopic processes at contacts between grains. Grain surfaces are rich in morphological features taking the shape of asperities on different spatial scales. Once grain assemblies are loaded, the contacts between grains respond with fracturing of asperities, with micro-cracking continuing over time after the loading process has ended. Experimental evidence collected was found consistent with the contact maturing hypothesis, which considers asperity fracturing (static fatigue) as the key cause of time-dependent evolution of sand properties under sustained loads. Statistical analyses of morphology on silica sand grain surfaces indicated a self-affine nature of the surface.  Asperities most vulnerable to damage are those in the upper range of height. A distinct element model was developed to mimic the process and to predict the consequences of contact maturing.

            Soils, such as silica sand, can improve their properties in time as a consequence of the maturing process. Individual contacts between grains evolve over time in response to sustained loads; the true contact area (or the number of contact points) increases. Consequently, the contact stiffness increases, causing an increase in stiffness of grain assemblies and sand deposits. While this phenomenon has beneficial influence on the foundation soils, its impact may reach far beyond the performance of civil engineering infrastructure. It is recognized that lunar and Martian soils (regolith) are rich in surface texture, and contact maturing is likely to be distinct in extraterrestrial granular materials. Accounting for the maturing process may prove to be important in planning for exploration of the Moon and Mars environments. Surface properties of grains and their evolution are important not only in soils, but also in powders and bulk solids handled in chemical, pharmaceutical, mining, or food industries.

Modified by: Radoslaw L Michalowski
